div.p: Greetings. The letter from you, most learned Coelius, was delivered to me by Mr. Hieronymus Massarius, in which you so earnestly request that I clear your name with Mr. Gwalther, my brother-in-law and dearest relative. Indeed, since I had never heard anything about this from him, I was surprised at first when I read your letter, and I could not rest until I had faithfully shared your letter with him. He was also surprised and responded only that he had never seen those poems, nor did he know what they were written about: it is far from him to have attributed the authorship to you. I did not want you to be unaware of this so that you might be more at ease. Live and farewell.
To the most distinguished Mr. Coelius Secundus Curio, most learned professor of the Basel school, esteemed lord and my dearest brother. Basel.
